steps.title: You Have All the Pieces
steps.narration: You've learned to ask deep questions. You've learned to see and analyze data. You've learned to build real things. Now it's time to put it all together and solve a real problem.

steps.title: Start with Questions
steps.narration: Every solution starts with understanding. Go six levels deep to truly understand the problem. Don't jump to solutions‚Äîunderstand the root causes first.

steps.title: Gather Data
steps.narration: Collect information about your problem. What resources exist? What do people say? What specific data would help? Organize what you find and look for patterns.

steps.title: Find Insights
steps.narration: Patterns in your data reveal opportunities. What's missing? What could be better? Your insights guide what to build. Data without insight is just noise.

steps.title: Build the Solution
steps.narration: Now you build! Use Cursor and AI to create something that addresses the problem. Iterate‚Äîbuild a first version, test it, then improve. Real solutions evolve.

steps.title: Choose Your Problem
steps.narration: Pick one problem to solve. It should be real‚Äîsomething you've actually observed. Specific‚Äînot too broad. And solvable‚Äîsomething you can actually address with a tool or resource.

steps.title: Deep Understanding
steps.narration: Use ChatGPT to go six levels deep. Keep asking why about each answer. Document all six levels. This helps you build a better solution because you truly understand the problem.

steps.title: Gather Your Data
steps.narration: What resources or solutions already exist? What do people say about this problem? What specific data would help‚Äîlocations, prices, reviews? Organize everything you find.

steps.title: Build with AI
steps.narration: Use Cursor to build your solution. Describe what you want, explain the problem, list the features. Make it professional and easy to use. Then iterate‚Äîimprove based on what works.

steps.title: Deploy and Test
steps.narration: Put your solution on GitHub Pages so it's live on the internet. Share it with two or three people who might use it. Get their feedback, then make improvements. Real solutions need real users.

steps.title: Your Portfolio
steps.narration: Your portfolio showcases everything you've learned. It includes work from each week plus your capstone project. This is proof that you can solve real problems.

steps.title: Present Your Work
steps.narration: You'll present your capstone to the group. Cover the problem, your research, the data you gathered, demo your solution, and share what you learned. Keep it short‚Äîthree to five minutes.

steps.title: Show, Don't Tell
steps.narration: Demo your actual project. Let them see it work. Quality over quantity. Be proud‚Äîyou built something real. That's something most people never do.

steps.title: You're a Builder Now
steps.narration: Congratulations! You've completed the academy. You're not just a consumer of technology anymore. You're a builder. You're a problem solver. The world needs more people like you.

steps.title: Keep Going
steps.narration: This is just the beginning. Keep building, stay curious, help others, and level up. The best time to start solving problems was yesterday. The second best time is right now. You have the skills‚Äînow go use them!

questions.question: Why might jumping to solutions before deep questioning be more dangerous than having no solution at all?
options: Because it wastes time that could be spent researching better tools
Because solving the wrong problem well can make the real problem invisible and harder to address later
Because it shows you don't care about the process
Because teachers won't give you credit for skipping steps
questions.explanation: When you solve the wrong problem effectively, you create the illusion of progress. This makes the real problem harder to see and address because everyone thinks it's 'handled.' A well-executed solution to the wrong problem is more dangerous than no solution because it consumes resources, builds false confidence, and obscures the actual need. Understanding root causes through deep questioning prevents this trap.

questions.question: You're gathering data about a problem and find two contradictory patterns. What's the most valuable way to think about this contradiction?
options: Discard one data source as unreliable and move forward with the other
The contradiction itself is the insight‚Äîit reveals a hidden complexity or multiple user needs
Average the two patterns to find a middle ground
Continue gathering more data until the contradiction resolves itself
questions.explanation: Contradictions in data aren't problems to eliminate‚Äîthey're insights waiting to be understood. When patterns conflict, it often reveals that different groups experience the problem differently, or that the problem has multiple facets you hadn't considered. This complexity is valuable information that can lead to more nuanced, effective solutions. The instinct to resolve contradictions by choosing one side or averaging loses this depth.

questions.question: What's the relationship between the quality of your questions and the type of data you'll naturally gather?
options: There's no relationship‚Äîdata gathering is independent of your questions
Better questions lead to more data, and more data is always better
Deep questions cause you to notice relevant patterns and connections that shallow questions would miss entirely
Questions help you organize data after you've collected it
questions.explanation: The questions you ask fundamentally shape what you can see. When you've gone six levels deep on a problem, you develop a framework for recognizing relevant patterns, connections, and gaps that someone with surface-level understanding would walk right past. It's not about gathering more data‚Äîit's about your questions making certain data meaningful and visible. Your question depth determines your pattern-recognition capacity.

questions.question: A classmate has gathered extensive data but can't find insights. What's the most likely root cause of this block?
options: They haven't gathered enough data yet and need to collect more
They lack the technical skills to analyze data properly
They're looking for insights in the data itself rather than in the gaps, tensions, and absences the data reveals
Their data sources are too diverse and need to be more focused
questions.explanation: Data doesn't contain insights‚Äîdata reveals the edges where insights emerge. The most powerful insights often come from what's missing, what's contradictory, what people avoid talking about, or what everyone assumes but no one questions. If you're only looking at what the data says directly, you miss the deeper story. Insights live in the tension between what is and what could be, not in the data points themselves.

questions.question: During the building phase, you realize your insights were partially wrong. What does this reveal about the problem-solving process?
options: You failed at the earlier steps and need to start over completely
The process is iterative‚Äîbuilding tests your understanding and refines your insights in ways thinking alone cannot
You should have spent more time in the data gathering phase
Your questions weren't deep enough initially
questions.explanation: Building is not just the final step‚Äîit's a form of inquiry. When you build, you're testing your understanding against reality in a way that reveals assumptions you didn't know you had. Discovering that your insights need refinement isn't failure; it's the process working correctly. The problem-solving cycle isn't linear‚Äîeach phase informs the others. Building often reveals new questions, which lead to new data needs, which generate refined insights. This is growth, not failure.

questions.question: Why does the process emphasize 'data without insight is just noise' rather than 'insight without data is just speculation'?
options: Because data is more important than insight in problem-solving
Because most people over-collect data without developing the interpretive lens to make it meaningful
Because speculation is actually valuable in creative problem-solving
Because the course focuses on data skills more than thinking skills
questions.explanation: While both statements are true, the emphasis reveals the more common failure mode: gathering extensive data while failing to develop the interpretive framework that transforms information into understanding. Many people hide behind data collection, treating it as productive work while avoiding the harder task of sense-making. Data is easier to gather than insights are to develop. The warning isn't that data is unimportant‚Äîit's that data without the cognitive work of interpretation is a comfortable form of procrastination disguised as progress.

questions.question: You're choosing between two problems: one you observed directly in your life, and one that sounds more impressive but you've only read about. What's the deeper trade-off you're actually making?
options: Between appearing smart to others versus actually developing real problem-solving skills
Between an easy project and a challenging one
Between originality and copying existing solutions
Between finishing quickly and taking your time
questions.explanation: This choice reveals whether you're optimizing for external validation or internal growth. The problem you've observed directly gives you tacit knowledge‚Äîyou understand the context, the emotional weight, the real constraints in ways that reading about a problem never can. That lived understanding is your competitive advantage and your richest learning opportunity. Impressive-sounding problems you haven't experienced force you to build on shallow understanding, which teaches you to be confident without depth‚Äîthe opposite of what this academy develops.

questions.question: When going six levels deep, you reach level 4 and realize the problem you chose isn't actually what you thought it was. What's the most growth-oriented response?
options: Continue with the original problem anyway since you've already invested time
Restart completely with a different problem from scratch
Recognize this reframing as valuable insight and adjust your problem statement based on your deeper understanding
Stop at level 4 since going deeper has led to confusion
questions.explanation: Discovery that challenges your initial framing isn't a detour‚Äîit's exactly what deep questioning is designed to produce. Most people never reach the depth where their assumptions get challenged, so they solve surface problems elegantly. When level 4 reveals that your problem is actually something different, that's your understanding maturing in real-time. The best problem-solvers hold their problem statements loosely enough to let deeper inquiry reshape them. Rigidity protects your ego; flexibility develops your capacity.

questions.question: You're gathering data and find that a solution similar to yours already exists. How should this shape your thinking?
options: Abandon your project since there's no point in recreating something
Copy their solution exactly to save time
Study why existing solutions exist, what gaps they have, and what your unique insight adds‚Äîtheir existence validates the problem space
Ignore the existing solutions and pretend they don't exist
questions.explanation: Existing solutions are data, not defeat. Their presence proves the problem is real and worth solving‚Äîvalidation, not invalidation. The deeper work is understanding: Why do existing solutions have the gaps they have? What constraints shaped them? What did they optimize for? Your unique perspective and understanding might address the problem from a different angle or for a different context. Most innovation isn't inventing entirely new problem spaces‚Äîit's bringing fresh insight to existing ones. The question isn't 'has this been done?' but 'what understanding can I add?'

questions.question: While building with AI, you keep getting results that technically work but don't feel right. What's likely happening?
options: The AI isn't capable enough and you need better tools
You haven't articulated your actual intent clearly, often because you're still discovering what you really want through the building process
You're being too picky and should accept what works
Your problem wasn't specific enough at the start
questions.explanation: This feeling of 'not quite right' is your tacit knowledge speaking‚Äîyou understand something about the problem that you haven't yet made explicit, even to yourself. Building is a dialogue between your explicit understanding (what you can articulate) and your implicit understanding (what you sense but can't yet name). When results feel off, it's usually because you're discovering new layers of your own understanding through the attempt to externalize it. This isn't a failure of tools or planning‚Äîit's taste developing in real-time. The solution is to slow down and interrogate that feeling: what specifically feels wrong? That articulation process often clarifies what you actually want.

questions.question: You deploy your solution and your first user struggles with something you found obvious. What's the deepest lesson here?
options: Users need better instructions or tutorials
You didn't test thoroughly enough before deploying
Your deep immersion in the problem has made you blind to the beginner's experience‚Äîexpertise creates a knowledge gap you can't see from inside
The user isn't trying hard enough to understand your solution
questions.explanation: This is the curse of knowledge manifesting. After going six levels deep and building the solution, you've developed sophisticated mental models that make certain things 'obvious' to you. But your user doesn't have those models‚Äîthey're experiencing your solution with the confusion you had at level 0. This gap isn't a flaw in your user or your solution; it's an inevitable consequence of expertise. The deepest lesson is humility: what feels obvious to you required all your research and building to become obvious. Good builders remember and design for the perspective they've outgrown. This is why real user testing is irreplaceable‚Äîit shows you your own blind spots.

questions.question: What's the real purpose of the 'iterate based on feedback' step‚Äîbeyond just improving the product?
options: To make users feel heard and involved in the process
To develop the emotional and cognitive capacity to separate your ego from your work and see criticism as data rather than attack
To find bugs and fix technical issues
To make sure the project meets teacher requirements
questions.explanation: The technical improvements from iteration are valuable, but the deeper transformation is psychological. Learning to receive feedback without defensiveness, to see your work as separate from your worth, to get curious about criticism rather than wounded‚Äîthese are the meta-skills that determine whether you'll grow as a builder or plateau. Most people can't iterate effectively because they can't emotionally handle their work being imperfect. When you build that capacity, you unlock exponential growth because every piece of feedback becomes fuel rather than threat. This emotional maturity is rarer and more valuable than technical skill.

questions.question: When presenting your capstone, you have the urge to over-explain or apologize for what's 'not done yet.' What's driving this urge, and what does resisting it teach you?
options: It's just nervousness that everyone feels when presenting
The fear that your work won't be seen as enough, and resisting it teaches you to let your work speak and trust that 'done' is better than 'perfect'
You want to manage expectations so people won't judge you harshly
You're being thorough by acknowledging limitations
questions.explanation: The apology impulse reveals a deeper fear: that you and your work will be judged as insufficient. But here's the reality‚Äîyou built something real and put it into the world, which most people never do. Over-explaining or apologizing doesn't protect you; it diminishes your work and trains you to hedge rather than own. Resisting this urge teaches you to trust that completion is valuable, that your work has worth independent of its perfection, and that confidence isn't arrogance‚Äîit's respecting your own effort. This is the psychological shift from student to builder.

questions.question: During your presentation, someone asks a critical question you don't know the answer to. What's the most growth-oriented response?
options: Deflect or give a vague answer to avoid looking unprepared
Say 'I don't know' and offer to investigate it‚Äîdemonstrating that not-knowing is a starting point for inquiry, not a failure
Get defensive and explain why the question isn't fair
Pretend the question doesn't matter to your project
questions.explanation: The instinct to hide gaps in knowledge is strong because we're trained that not-knowing signals inadequacy. But builders and researchers know differently: not-knowing is simply the boundary of your current understanding, and acknowledging it honestly is the first step toward expanding that boundary. When you say 'I don't know, but that's a great question and here's how I'd investigate it,' you demonstrate intellectual integrity and curiosity‚Äîboth rarer and more valuable than having every answer. This response also models for your peers that inquiry doesn't end at presentation, and that questions are opportunities, not threats.

questions.question: What's the difference between 'showing' your project versus 'telling' about it that matters most for your growth?
options: Showing is more engaging for the audience than telling
Showing forces you to build something functional enough to demonstrate, which is a higher bar than something you can just describe
Telling takes too much time in a short presentation
Showing uses visual aids which are more memorable
questions.explanation: The power of 'show, don't tell' isn't just presentation technique‚Äîit's a forcing function for quality. When you know you'll have to demo your work live, you can't hide behind descriptions or intentions. It has to work. This constraint pushes you to finish, to handle edge cases, to make it genuinely usable. Many people can describe impressive ideas; far fewer can show them working. The shift from 'I'm building something that would...' to 'Here, let me show you how it works' is the shift from aspiration to achievement. That gap‚Äîbetween what you can talk about and what you can demonstrate‚Äîis where real capability lives.

questions.question: Your portfolio showcases projects from each week. What does this collection reveal that any single project cannot?
options: It shows you completed all the assignments on time
It demonstrates your range and your capacity to apply a consistent problem-solving process across different domains
It makes your portfolio look more impressive with more projects
It gives you more things to talk about in your presentation
questions.explanation: Any single project might be luck or passion for that specific topic. But a portfolio that applies deep questioning, data gathering, insight generation, and building across multiple problem spaces reveals something deeper: you have a transferable method. You're not just someone who solved one problem‚Äîyou're someone who has a process for solving problems in general. This is the difference between a hobbyist and a practitioner. The collection demonstrates that your capability isn't domain-specific luck; it's a reproducible approach. That's what employers, collaborators, and educators are really looking for‚Äînot single achievements, but reliable capacity.

questions.question: The course says 'you're not just a consumer of technology anymore‚Äîyou're a builder.' What's the most profound shift this identity change enables?
options: You can now put 'programmer' on your resume
You stop waiting for permission or perfect conditions and start creating solutions to problems you notice
You understand technology better than most people
You can help family and friends with their computer problems
questions.explanation: The identity shift from consumer to builder changes your fundamental relationship with problems. Consumers wait for someone else to solve things. Builders see problems as opportunities they have agency to address. This isn't about technical skills‚Äîit's about locus of control. When you see yourself as a builder, every frustration becomes a potential project, every 'I wish this existed' becomes 'I could make this exist.' This shift from passive to active, from waiting to creating, from consuming to producing‚Äîthis is the transformation that compounds over a lifetime. The technical skills are tools; the builder identity is the engine that drives everything else.

questions.question: Why does the course end with 'the best time to start solving problems was yesterday, the second best time is right now'?
options: It's motivational language to make you feel good about finishing
It emphasizes that waiting for 'perfect timing' or 'more preparation' is the resistance that stops most people from ever building anything
It's saying you should have started earlier in the course
It creates urgency so you'll continue paying for more courses
questions.explanation: This isn't motivation‚Äîit's diagnosis of the primary obstacle most people face: the belief that they need one more skill, one more credential, one more tool, one more tutorial before they can start building. That belief is comforting because it lets you feel productive (by learning) without risking failure (by building). But builders know that starting imperfectly and iterating is the only path. You already have enough to start solving real problems. The course is telling you: the gap between your current capability and 'ready' is a myth designed to keep you comfortable. You've been ready since week 1. The question was never capability‚Äîit was courage to start without permission. Now you know you already have both.
